A sum of numbers is infinite iff one of them is infinite

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_1} {M : Type u_4} [inst : AddCommMonoid M] {s : Finset ι} {f : ι → WithTop M},
  (Finset.sum s fun i => f i) = ⊤ ↔ ∃ i ∈ s, f i = ⊤
name: WithTop.sum_eq_top_iff
docString: A sum of numbers is infinite iff one of them is infinite

The set of prime natural numbers is infinite.

name: Nat.infinite_setOf_prime
docString: The set of prime natural numbers is infinite.

This is Euclid's theorem on the infinitude of primes. The theorem states that for every natural number `n`, there exists a prime number `p` such that `p` is greater than or equal to `n`. In other words, there are infinitely many prime numbers, and for any given natural number, there will always be a prime number that is greater than or equal to that number.

name: Nat.exists_infinite_primes
docString: This is Euclid's theorem on the infinitude of primes. The theorem states that for every natural number `n`, there exists a prime number `p` such that `p` is greater than or equal to `n`. In other words, there are infinitely many prime numbers, and for any given natural number, there will always be a prime number that is greater than or equal to that number.

Any infinite set of naturals is denumerable.

type: (s : Set ℕ) → [inst : DecidablePred fun x => x ∈ s] → [inst : Infinite ↑s] → Denumerable ↑s
name: Nat.Subtype.denumerable
docString: Any infinite set of naturals is denumerable.

For all natural numbers `n`, the real number representation `n` is finite.

name: ENNReal.nat_ne_top
docString: For all natural numbers `n`, the real number representation `n` is finite.

This theorem states that for any ordinal 'o', it is not possible for 'o' to be less than zero. In other words, no ordinal number is less than zero.

name: Ordinal.not_lt_zero
docString: This theorem states that for any ordinal 'o', it is not possible for 'o' to be less than zero. In other words, no ordinal number is less than zero.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} {M : Matroid α} [self : Matroid.InfiniteRk M], ∃ B, M.Base B ∧ Set.Infinite B
name: Matroid.InfiniteRk.exists_infinite_base

For any ordinal number 'o', o is non-zero if and only if o ≥ 1.

name: Ordinal.one_le_iff_ne_zero
docString: For any ordinal number 'o', o is non-zero if and only if o ≥ 1.

This theorem states that for any real number `r` greater than 1, the function that maps a natural number `n` to `n` is little-o of the function that maps `n` to `r^n` as `n` approaches infinity. In other words, in terms of growth rates as `n` goes to infinity, `n` grows significantly slower than `r^n` for any `r` greater than 1. This is expressed using the little-o notation (`=o[Filter.atTop]`), which formalizes the concept of one function growing much slower than another in the limit.

type: ∀ {R : Type u_4} [inst : NormedRing R] {r : ℝ}, 1 < r → Nat.cast =o[Filter.atTop] fun n => r ^ n
name: isLittleO_coe_const_pow_of_one_lt
docString: This theorem states that for any real number `r` greater than 1, the function that maps a natural number `n` to `n` is little-o of the function that maps `n` to `r^n` as `n` approaches infinity. In other words, in terms of growth rates as `n` goes to infinity, `n` grows significantly slower than `r^n` for any `r` greater than 1. This is expressed using the little-o notation (`=o[Filter.atTop]`), which formalizes the concept of one function growing much slower than another in the limit.

Type of natural numbers with infinity (`⊤`)

name: PartENat
docString: Type of natural numbers with infinity (`⊤`)

For any infinite set of natural numbers and any positive natural number, there exist distinct elements with the same remainder when divided by that number.

type: ∀ {s : Set ℕ}, s.Infinite → ∀ {k : ℕ}, 0 < k → ∃ m ∈ s, ∃ n ∈ s, m < n ∧ k.ModEq m n
name: Nat.exists_lt_modEq_of_infinite
docString: For any infinite set of natural numbers and any positive natural number, there exist distinct elements with the same remainder when divided by that number.

This theorem states that the ordinal number one is less than omega. In other words, the ordinal corresponding to the number one is smaller than the first infinite ordinal, denoted as omega. Omega is defined as the order type of the set of natural numbers, which means it corresponds to the concept of "countable infinity" in set theory.

name: Ordinal.one_lt_omega
docString: This theorem states that the ordinal number one is less than omega. In other words, the ordinal corresponding to the number one is smaller than the first infinite ordinal, denoted as omega. Omega is defined as the order type of the set of natural numbers, which means it corresponds to the concept of "countable infinity" in set theory.

The number of infinite real places of the number field `K`.

type: (K : Type u_2) → [inst : Field K] → [inst : NumberField K] → ℕ
name: NumberField.InfinitePlace.NrRealPlaces
docString: The number of infinite real places of the number field `K`.

The number of infinite complex places of the number field `K`.

type: (K : Type u_2) → [inst : Field K] → [inst : NumberField K] → ℕ
name: NumberField.InfinitePlace.NrComplexPlaces
docString: The number of infinite complex places of the number field `K`.

There are finitely many subsets of a given finite set

type: ∀ {α : Type u} {a : Set α}, Set.Finite a → Set.Finite {b | b ⊆ a}
name: Set.Finite.finite_subsets
docString: There are finitely many subsets of a given finite set

Infinite ordinals that are cardinals are unbounded.

type: Set.Unbounded (fun x x_1 => x < x_1) {b | Cardinal.ord (Ordinal.card b) = b ∧ Ordinal.omega ≤ b}
name: Cardinal.ord_card_unbounded'
docString: Infinite ordinals that are cardinals are unbounded.
